H0.text: They are both flexible, as shown by the long vine of an ivy plant and the trunk of an oak tree.

H1.text: They are both stiff, as the long vine of an ivy plant and the trunk of an oak tree share this property.

H2.text: They both make food for a plant, as both the long vine of an ivy plant and the trunk of an oak tree do.

H3.text: They both give support to a plant, as the long vine of an ivy plant and the trunk of an oak tree provide structural support.

A4.text: The ivy also blocks the sun from the trees that need it for photosynthesis.

A5.text: Growth away from light allows the vine to reach a tree trunk, which it can then climb to brighter regions.

A6.text: Vines are able to grow in both deep shade and full sun due to their uniquely wide range of phenotypic plasticity.

A7.text: The climbing fetterbush (Pieris phillyreifolia) is a woody shrub-vine which climbs without clinging roots, tendrils, or thorns.
